The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

comments: Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Very helpful
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nicholas Hodges
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nick hodges
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nick graded my memos. Otherwise didn't work with/attend TF sessions.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  I worked with both Nick and Z.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Zaheer Tajani
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nick Hodges
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nick was a very helpful TA but Zaheer didn't always provide clear answers and wasn't as approachable.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Zaheer Tajani
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  I interacted mostly closely with Zaheer Tajani. Both he and Chris were really excellent. Very available and extremely helpful.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  I interacted almost exclusively with Z. Did not reach out to Nick for much help.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nicholas Hodges
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  I don't know why Z (Zaheer Tajani) is not in the drop-down box above but I interacted with Z most closely.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Zaheer Tajani
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  very helpful comments on the policy memos! Thank you!
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Z

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Good review of memos

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Really not a reflection on the teaching fellows, but since they were the ones grading the policy memos: it would have been really helpful to get examples of what a great policy memo is. Instead, we got feedback on our own after the fact, when it was too late. There was clearly something that you were hoping to see in these memos, both in terms of style/organization and content, and the instructions/writing tips/grading key were NOT helpful at all. In general, making sure that students know what is expected of them is a good thing. Seeing what others have done right is not going to stifle our creativity, but it will allow us to understand what it is that you actually want. It's the end of the semester and I am still not sure.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  All was great- the final review was very helpful. (I never attended TF sessions because they were all during my classes-- unfortunate). For grading the policy memo's I wish there was more substantive comments and less grammar, etc.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Accessible, timely. Provided thoughtful critiques of the policy memos.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nick was very accessible via email and did a fantastic job of explaining the material. Although he was only present at a few of the discussion sections, the ones he led were very well organized and I felt I got a lot out of them. Z was also very accessible via email. Z seemed to have the primary responsibility of leading the discussion sections, and for the most part did well in leading them. I do think there is room for him to improve with his style and pace. He would often rush through the material without really explaining anything. He also cancelled several discussion sections.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  I really appreciated Nick's responsiveness and willingness to provide extensive feedback on the policy memo's. Both he and Z also did a great job leading the discussion sections I attended.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  One of the best editors I've ever encountered - harsh but really valuable feedback.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Nick was the teaching assistant with whom I interacted the most. He was very helpful and receptive to questions, which was very important for me since I have no prior experience in law.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Z was very helpful and incredibly knowledgable of the material, although at times he seemed to make people feel embarrassed for not knowing things. Perhaps through his tone or approach, he could be more welcoming and conversational. This might make others more receptive to engaging him in questions/conversation about the material.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  He was great, but the feedback I got on my memo's was not as helpful.

Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  Z was very accessible and helpful during office hours and during sections (and outside via email as well). He does come off as a bit intimidating and intense, but he is very helpful.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  I didn't go to the lab.
Instructor: Nicholas Aaron Hodges  The TA was responsive and knowledgeable about the material.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Dan is a fantastic speaker. Stories are great to put things in context, but sometimes that gets in the way of the content. I thought we could have spent more time on technical/aspects of the law.
Esty's perspective is very valuable and will be missed. I felt that he focused more on providing his perspective rather than hard facts at times.
Esty is a very polished lecturer. We had a lot of material to cover but I feel like that was handled well and I learned a lot.
This course was very valuable for my education at Yale since I would like to be involved in policy. I have learned a tremendous amount of information.

Prof. Esty has an academic acumen unrivaled in his field by anyone else at the School of Forestry. He is a compelling speaker and his willingness to share his own experience was one of the better qualities of the lectures. However, Prof. Esty was always quick to leave class immediately once his lectures concluded. I think that if there were a door closer to the podium, he would have used that instead of having to walked through the auditorium to the back exit. I understand that he is very busy, but he was pretty much locked down once class ended unless you headed him by standing directly in his path.
12: I really appreciated how Dan took the time in the middle of the semester to collect suggestions and feedback on the course, and addressed most of them.

It's fairly obvious that Esty put little or no effort into this course. His outlines for this year were the same as previous years and the fact that he spent 95% of the time talking about the people he knows and the experiences he had in office rather than teaching the law was further proof.
Professor Esty and classes of this type in general are much better with a smaller class. If nothing else, a better large lecture room would have really improved the experience.
Excellent class- professor was organized and very engaging.

I felt that is class not very valuable at all. The reading was too much and cumbersome and did not teach you what you needed to know for lecture (except maybe the last 10 rushed minutes of class) lecture was a little policy mostly anecdotal and reflection of estys career. The material, at least for an environmental student should be a brief overview clarification of the policy but then the bull should be how to we think about and use envirknemtantl law as a tool for the improvements we want to accomplish. The reading should be digestible background and class should allow us to think about and get to real solutions or courses of action for progress. Ok you did stuff in the 90s for the epa but how can we learn from those lessons and be effective policy maker lobbyists in the future. This required more work in the part of the instructor, TAs and students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Gives a comprehensive overview of environmental law system in the US. Helpful and essential for anyone interested in the environment.

Esty's lecture style and experience at multiple levels of government were very valuable. Amazingly, the anecdotes never veered into "war stories" territory. They were always relevant to the course material being discussed that day.
Breadth and depth of law that it covers. Policy memos were helpful.

For students who do not have a background in law this course was very effective in introducing students to the most significant U.S. environmental laws and policies and the evolution of environmental policy over the last 60 years.
Broad overview of environmental law and policy. Interesting stories from Prof. Esty.
The policy memos - having these as an assignment helped clarify my learning on a number of laws and issues.
Great overview of environmental law - was really helpful to have this framework for other classes, and to help orient issues of environmental policy.
The policy memos were indeed challenging but were very important for learning how to apply the law and to think critically about how it can be improved.
Esty's lectures are engaging and very well-articulated. Really worth paying attention to and taking good notes on. His actual experience in the field is an immense resource.

Great that lectures supplemented the readings, but I resorted to reading case briefs after about 5 weeks because I could not keep up with the amount of material that I was required to be familiar with. The practice mid-term was a great supplement. Please continue to offer this.
I liked Professor Esty's very good experiences and stories of his practice of environmental law and policy.

It was great to learn about the foundations of environmental law in the US (which affected many other countries), and also to hear Dan's experiences and opinions on why the current system is facing problems, what potential solutions are there, and what lessons we should learn as future leaders in the field.
The readings.
Very interesting material which Professor Esty knows a lot about.
Professor was excellent, material was presented in a clear, logical manner, class was useful (esp. with the policy memos)

The professor has a wealth of experience, and it came across in the course. We covered a lot of material, and I feel like I have basic familiarity not just with the important environmental statutes of the day, but also with the processes involved with regulation and legislation.
Not even sure...
The course was well-organized and important concepts were clearly articulated.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It was a large class. This made it hard to foster real discussion. Dan did do his best, but there was a small group of students who did the vast majority of contributing.
This class has too much assigned readings. Having a more focused selection of reading material would be more helpful for students to allocate time and actually remember something from the readings.

I think we should spend more time on domestic issues, and delve further into the CWA, CAA, CERCLA etc, rather than spend time on global governance/trade etc. Most students were taking that class to get exposure to US environmental law, and most will work in the US. There are several classes dedicated to global governance/diplomacy etc. at FES that people can take if interested in these topics. There are no other environmental law classes. Trying to fit everything in one semester makes the scope of the class too wide. We cover everything, and nothing in depth. It's a little frustrating. In addition, it would be helpful to provide the students with samples of the main regulatory instruments for federal regulation - For instance, it would be great to get a glance at what a listing decision looks like under the ESA, or see what a NPDES permit is in practice. Further, writing policy memos on topics that we have not yet covered in class seems like a futile exercise. You end up putting a lot of time into researching topics, in addition to the readings, which are already quite long, and you write something subpar because a) you have no concrete experience so have to make things up as you go and cannot possibly be expected to have something meaningful to contribute to the debate after a couple days of research, and b) you have no concrete direction for writing the policy memos (see my comment on policy memo above). Let people delve into a topic they are interested in, and make the policy memo a semester long endeavor, with Nick and Zee available to review drafts during the writing process. This would be a much better learning experience. Lastly, please please please migrate class readings and documents to classesV2!! Nothing more frustrating than wasting time downloading documents one by one when you could download the materials for the entire semester in one click on classesV2. If that is not possible for some weird administrative reason, then please take a minute to put the documents in Yale Box, or some other sharing network. People are busy and technology should not get in the way. (I thought that was actually one of the main tenets of Dan's time at DEEP!)
Final exam too comprehensive to not have a set exam outline to study. To simply to know everything is completely unreasonable.
Visuals during lecture.

For FES students not having any other foundations of law class, it would be helpful to have a structured lesson or two and an assignment (to cement skills) on understanding how to search for federal statutes, regulations, and court cases and how to search the Federal Register. As environmental law evolves during our careers, we should know how to perform basic legal searches rather than relying on media to track developments in the field.
A final paper or series of short answers would have been a better exercise than the final exam. The exam led to too much cramming and not enough focused, thoughtful analysis.

A bit more clarity around the expectations for the class (especially the policy memos) would have been helpful, especially in a class that draws from so many different schools. For instance, knowing we'd be competing in the same distribution as the law students might have been helpful to know much earlier, so people could be strategic about how they invested their resources across their class schedules.

I don't like the way the assignments were structured. Having just two memos due before the final exam which is a huge chunk of the grade is not as helpful as other methods I believe. I understand that this is the way that most law classes are structured, but perhaps there can be a longer paper that touches on some overall important aspects of environmental law would be more helpful.

As much as I appreciated Dan's lecturing style (very impressive), I felt too many times that I spent the whole lecture writing down everything and not processing or thinking about the topics as much. It would be quite helpful if outlines of the lectures could be uploaded in advance so students can focus less on writing things down and more on thinking about the issues and engaging in discussion.
Esty forgetting he needs to teach law, not his rolodex.
The room and size. Perhaps required 1 hour small group discussion sections would help with this?
The policy memos could use a bit more instruction.

It is utterly absurd that Forestry students are graded on the same curve as Law students. It would be just as easy to have separate curves for Law and non-Law students, with grades given out in equal proportions. Law students have extensive advantages over those who have not taken law classes before. One rumor is that the course is graded on a single curve because the professor does not think grades of Forestry students matter as much to them. Different students are in different circumstances, and this should not be his decision to make. Some employers do care about grades, nearly all scholarships take grades into consideration, and grades are extremely important to those who will seek future schooling after Yale. It was almost entirely unclear what was expected of us for policy memos. Having clearer guidelines--or even a sample memo or two to look at--would have helped immensely.

It needs a complete overhaul. Maybe make it smaller or get the law students putt if they want to only learn all te statutes. Those can be learned on ones own time I want class to be learning how to actually work with this stuff and make change.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Sections were sometimes helpful. Nick and Zee are very clear, although Zee speaks too quickly.
The discussions were very helpful. However, I wish that they were held more often. Many times our discussion sections were cancelled due to a lack of questions.

I wasn't aware or sure if the "lab" sections were required and/or who 'my' TA was. I was also unsure if my grade was impacted by my participation in those sections. This could have been more clearly defined.

There was no requirement to go to discussion, but it was put in the final participation grade, which was helpful because some people are shy to raise their hands in front of 60+ other students during the regular session. But perhaps requiring students to attend a couple would be good, in the future.

In the beginning of the course it was hard to nail down what the nature of the section would be, since the course had students with huge range of legal and environmental expertise. I think the section ended up being more review sessions for each week recapping the main cases and concepts, which was definitely helpful for those students with less prior exposure or familiarity with the concepts. But that did mean there was less of a forum to discuss the ideas and policies.
I didn't do the lab.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am in engineering, and normally engineers do not take these courses, but I have particular interest in the topic and found that the extra work in this course was very valuable.
Broad foundation for a lot of my work.
See response to question 17.

As an FES MEM with little to no law exposure, this course provided a whirl-wind introduction to some of the most famous and impactful cases in American environmental law. I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in law and policy, or anyone who wants the opportunity to examine and critique the foundations and future of environmental law in the US (and the world.)
Environmental law is probably one of the most important courses that a student can take at FES.
This course satisfied a requirement for my industrial ecology and green design specialization.
Environmental law is important to every discipline and it was a necessary course to take in grad school.
This course is beneficial for any environmental manager.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: You can't really be an environmental manager without a good understanding of the law!
Understanding basics of environmental law and policy.
Curiosity.
See response to question 17.
I wanted to learn more about law and policy, and I do believe that this course served as a necessary foundation for my career.
To gain a more detailed understanding of environmental law and how environmental policy is created. This class satisfied this completely.
To fit my career interests and goals
I took this course to satisfy a requirement in my specialization, to get a grounding in environmental law, and to learn from Dan Esty.
Environmental law is important to every discipline and it was a necessary course to take in grad school.
To gain a broad understanding of environmental law.

I wanted a better understanding of envirknemtantl law and policy but not just a laundry list of statutes but how they ar being used ie how Obama is using the clean air act for climate change - that's new interesting innovative is some ways. Get me to think in ways that I can come up with solutions like that. I'm not here to learn history I'm hear to learn history understand it to move forwArd faster and better. Also the final asked us to do this a bit which is rediculous because we had no practice no learning in the class to then be able to do this in the exam.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes
yes.
Yes!
Yes.
yes

Yes and no - I received a broad overview into environmental law, which I really appreciate and think is very valuable. I am a bit shakier on my ability to comment on or evaluate law, but that may be a skill that's beyond the scope of this class.
Yes, very much so.
How to quickly summarize vase amounts of information, and to be able to have a brief conversation about why that information matters.

Most definitely so. I saw the issues we learned in class pop up everywhere in the news, and I gained a clearer understanding of environmental issues and how the legal and regulatory framework shapes the issues. One of the most eye-opening courses I have taken so far.
The knowledge I gained from readings-yes. My expectations for the professor-no.
Yes.
No

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep up with the readings. If you are a non-law student, attend some discussion sections, as they can provide insight regarding test preparation.
Take for sure. Mm this course is very informative.

Keep up with the readings, and take good notes on lectures and readings both - it will make your life much easier when it's time to study for the final. And don't study for the final by yourself, it's very helpful to talk things through with other students.
Good overview of environmental law, but not much depth into any of the statutes.
The framework this course provides is very helpful, but it's an enormous time commitment - be sure you're ready to devote enough hours to it before signing on.
This class is challenging but very rewarding.
Pay close attention to the first day's lecture. He sets up the rest of the class in that first day and indicates what he'll emphasize on the final. Take good notes on the lecture.

As an FES MEM with little to no law exposure, this course provided a whirl-wind introduction to some of the most famous and impactful cases in American environmental law. I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in law and policy, or anyone who wants the opportunity to examine and critique the foundations and future of environmental law in the US (and the world.)
Try to get to Professory Esty's hours ASAP and don't forget to schedule that in advance. That was one thing I didn't get as much from the course since he was always so busy: not enough 1-on-1 time.

Don't get intimidated by all the readings or the legal jargon, and definitely take the class! It is mostly US-focused, but the principles learned in the class have worldwide implications. Dan is an amazing teacher and very supportive of his students.
Take another law course with a more interested professor
Definitely take this course with Prof. Esty. He's one of the best professors/lecturers at FES and the material is relevant for any environmental manager/scientist.
Maybe law students got more out of this class
